description:
'''Snap music''' (also known as '''snap''', '''ringtone rap''' or '''snap rap''') is a [[subgenre]] of [[Hip-hop|hip hop music]] derived from [[crunk]] that originated in southern United States in the 2000s, in [[Bankhead (Atlanta)|Bankhead]], [[Atlanta|West Atlanta]], United States. It achieved mainstream popularity throughout the mid-late 2000s, but declined shortly thereafter. Popular snap artists include [[D4L]], Ramage, [[Dem Franchize Boys]] and K-Rab.

Tracks commonly consist of an [[Roland TR-808|808]] [[bass drum]], [[Hi-hat (instrument)|hi-hat]], [[Bass (instrument)|bass]], [[Snap (fingers)|snapping]], a main [[Groove (music)|groove]] and a vocal track. Snap songs may also incorporate whistling. Hit snap songs include "[[Lean wit It, Rock wit It]]" by [[Dem Franchize Boys]], "[[Snap Yo Fingers]]" by [[Lil Jon]], "[[Laffy Taffy (song)|Laffy Taffy]]" by [[D4L]], "Ya Lil (Al Anisa Farah)" by Ramage, "[[It's Goin' Down (Yung Joc song)|It's Goin' Down]]" by [[Yung Joc]] and "[[Crank That (Soulja Boy)]]" by [[Soulja Boy Tell 'Em]], and "[[Look at Her]]" by One Chance.

Crunk has been called the "predecessor of snap". ''Hip Hop DX'' magazine described snap music as a "laid back version of its forbearer{{sic}}, crunk music".
